data.title: Arseniy Vorozheykin: Soviet aviator (1912 - 2001)
data.meta_description: Arseniy Vorozheykin: Soviet aviator (1912 - 2001); Aviator, Pilot, Aircraft pilot, Writer; From: Russia
data.text:
He served in the army from 1931 to 1933. He was a Red Army soldier of the 17th rifle division, and served in Gorky (town). After being transferred to the reserve, he entered the Higher Communist Agricultural School in Gorky, but he graduated only from the first course. From 1934 until his retirement in 1957, he served again in the Red Army. In 1937 he graduated from the Kharkov Military Aviation Pilot School. From November 1937 to July 1938 he served as a junior pilot in the 53rd Bomber Regiment. Then he was sent again to study, and in 1939 he graduated from the six-month course of pilot commissars. From January 1939 he was the Commissioner of the squadron in the 53rd Bomber Aviation Regiment.

From May 1939 - Squadron Commissioner in the 22nd Fighter Aviation Regiment. In this position, he participated in the battles on the Khalkhin Gol River in May–September 1939 . There, Vorozheikin conducted 30 air battles, as a result of which they were personally shot down 6 Japanese aircraft.

From February 1940- the military commissar of the aviation squadron of the 38th fighter regiment of the Air Force of the Baltic Military District . In this position, he participated in the Soviet-Finnish war of 1939-1940 .

Stella A. V. Vorozheykin and V. G. Ryazanov in the Nizhny Novgorod Kremlin. From March 1940 - deputy squadron commander for political affairs, and from March 1941- squadron commander in the 342nd fighter regiment of the Transcaucasian Military District .

In 1942 he graduated from the Air Force Academy. Since August 1942, participates in the battles of the Great Patriotic War on the Kalinin and Voronezh (from October 20, 1943, 1st Ukrainian ) fronts. From August 1942 - Deputy Commander, from July 1943 - Commander of the Fighter Aviation Squadron of the 728th Fighter Aviation Regiment of the 256th Fighter Aviation Division of the 5th Fighter Aviation Corps in the 2nd Air Army . By January 1944, the squadron commander Captain Vorozheikin made 78 combat missions. In 32 air battles personally destroyed 19 enemy aircraft.

Decree of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR dated February 4, 1944 for courage and heroism shown in battles with the German fascist invaders, Arseniy Vorozheikin was awarded the title Hero of the Soviet Union with the award of the Order of Lenin and the Gold Star medal (No. 2043).

In the next six months, the squadron commander A. Vorozheykin A. made another 28 sorties with participation in 14 air battles. As a result, they personally shot down 11 enemy aircraft. For these exploits, by the Decree of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR of August 19, 1944, Captain Vorozheikin Arseny Vasilyevich was awarded the second Gold Star medal (No. 28). From July 1944 - Deputy Commander of the 32nd Fighter Aviation Regiment of the 256th Fighter Aviation Division. From October 1944, Vorozheikin held the position of senior instructor-pilot of the Main Directorate of Combat Training of Frontal Aviation of the Red Army, while continuing to make combat missions until the end of the war.

On May 1, 1945, the pilots of the 2nd Air Army Guard, captain V. K. Novoselov and Major N. A. Malinovsky, accompanied by 16 fighters under the command of twice Hero of the Soviet Union, Colonel A. V. Vorozheikin, included in the Heroes of the Soviet Union V. N. Buyanova, I.P. Laveykina, P.I. Peskov and other pilots appeared over the Reichstag and dropped red banners on parachutes. “Victory” was written on one of them, “Glory to the Soviet soldiers who hoisted the Victory Banner over Berlin” on the back side, and “Long live May 1” on the other .

In total, he completed approximately 400 combat sorties, personally shot down 52 enemy aircraft (including six shot down in Khalkhin Gol), and shared 14 group victories, making him one of the most successful aces of the Soviet Air Force.
